setup.question: What is likely the next step in the story?
answers: Bob and Quezy work with Starre to come up with a solution to both their problems,
Bob and Quezy deliver the asteroid, and Starre marries Mac.

Text.text: The story is about Quezy and Mac, who haul asteroids for a job. They take a job from a millionaire who requests a very specific asteroid, and when they find it, they also find Starre, who has claimed it as their home. As they're discussing who gets the asteroid, another group of asteroid haulers comes in and attacks the three, before stealing the asteroid. Starre, Bob, and Quezy regroup and look for them. Later, they become close:
They find out that Starre is the daughter of the millionaire, who requested a rare asteroid to marry someone on to avoid an arranged marriage.
Starre and Bob towards the end:
Starre describes how her grandfather, the
. Despite Bob lusting over her, Starre will inevitable have to comply with her comandeering grandfather and marry Mac,
. Not only is her grandfather an unbudging curmudgeon, he is
, who places the asteroid order
. A rich, immovable old man will (albeit unfortunately) most likely get his way in marrying off his granddaughter.
Could you both agree upon a summary of the story up to this point?

The summary is that Bob and Quezy are asteroid miners who find Starre on an asteroid they need. When trying to come to an agreement, they are attacked, and they team up to go find the asteroid. Bob finds Starre attractive and falls in love with her. That is the summary up to this point, any challenge B gives I can provide ev to prove. They're pretty close at this point, and the text is pretty explicit, Bob loves Starre, why would he deliver the asteroid, screwing Starre over and also losing her to her arranged marriage, it doesn't make sense. Towards the end, when they're discussing the marriage, his tone is clear:

I agree with A on the summary, but A's own quotation shows evidence for the futility of solving Starre's problem - she is resigned to the fact she must marry Mac, and given the characterization of her overbearing, incredibly rich grandfather, it seems like the most likely event would be for her to be forced to comply. Unromantic, sure, but most likely. On top of that, Bob and Quezy's problem is that they are losing money:
. In order to save their livelihood, they are
, it being the asteroid. They are so desperate in that

Though B's story seems more realistic this is a story, in the end, so I'm inclined to believe the more optimistic prediction.

A: can you explain what both of their problems are and how they could work out a solution, or an indication that they are going to try to work out a solution.

B: Your account seems contradictory, Starre appears to be an alien, both inferred through her name and from the fact that she's literally on an asteroid; how then can her grandpa be from Philadelphia? Can you reconcile this?
Bob is very against the idea of Starre marrying Mac.

This is right before the last quote I gave. He is about to confess to her, but she says Mac is an issue, and he becomes mad as a result. Bob's problem is that he needs to give the asteroid to Starre's grandfather to get payed, but if he does then Starre is forced into an arranged marriage. There's little evidence for what's going to happen next, so judge, you do  have to make a leap of faith here, but wouldn't it be a shitty story if they didn't find a resolution to the marriage/delivery issue? Bob loves Starre, they'll try to find a solution.

Sure, the fact she is on an asteroid is science fiction creative liberty. I can't definitively say she isn't an alien, Quezy isn't exactly a common human name either, but I can offer more proof that she is in fact Andrew Burnside's granddaughter,
. Further info on Starre:
. Seems like fairly human characteristics.

Gonna run one last round. A you seem to be using a lot of conjecture but can you provide any quotes for the latter half of your recent speech? B, can you provide ev that despite Bob being infatuated with Starre he'll still send her back to Mac?
I can only give evidence of Bob's feelings for Starre. After mentioning how she may be forced to marry Mac, Bob becomes agitated

. He's clearly not happy about this. The latter half of my speech is just pointing out that this is a work of fiction, and the writer wants to make it interesting, so he would air on the side of them working together, not just taking the easy way out. This is all the evidence there is, and most importantly, all of the evidence about Bob loving Starre comes after all of B's evidence about their obligations. Now that Bob loves Starre, he's willing to compromise. He's angry about the arranged marriage, even though he knows his delivery of the asteroid is what can cause it to happen.
It's not up to Bob to 'send her back', he doesn't own her, he's merely a lustful dude helping out a girl he thinks is pretty:
. Gross, Bob. I welcome A to prove that there is any reciprocation from Starre in regard to Bob's infatuation. Their argumentation remains as conjecture.
B seems to have run out of steam and the last speech is ev, I think that even though A has slightly less ev the question's nature as a hypothetical means I should favor explanation.
lowkey have no clue - this story could go either way, just because of the fact that the title etc doesn't give me any inclination of what is true and not true - therefore 50/50 for now

ok im not convinced by both sides, they both seem to paint slightly different stories and no one is really focusing on this mac character that starre has to or doesn't have to marry, actually upon reinspection B talks about Mac a little more and it makes sense, however still need more evidence about this story

still not really sure, the summary didnt help me that much, I feel like in terms of what makes the most sense, why would an author write a story that ends in an asteroid being delivered and an unhappy heroine. So I am now leaning a little more heavily towards A although B does an excellent job of making their points

Yeah A said enough to convince me, although this was kind of a tough debate to judge due to the fact that A is right that I do have to make a leap of faith when it comes to making my decision. Also am i the only one who felt like B just didnt say anything useful in their last speech. Like they just keep going on about the fact that she is a grand daughter which is wierd like thats not the debate at hand. That argumentation furthered me to vote for A with a much higher confidence.

answers.reason for outcome: B lost steam and didn't use the whole argument length.

I think this was a tough debate to judge 
- glad i continued the debate because my initial analysis was wrong 
- had to make more leaps and bounds with this debate because there was no explicit evidence 
- continuing the debate lead me to see the holes in B's argumentation 
- had to use a lot more logic to get through to this and the wuotes werent that helpful - but the lofgic presented by A made the most sense
B's last speech really lost all confidence which probably helped with the judge's decision, also my overall argumentation.
